title: Banks and business wrangle with zero interest rate floors
text:
Bank customers on the other hand are likely to be less than thrilled to find out their interest rates will never fall below the bank’s margin.

Mr Elias said loan agreements are typically structured with a floating rate consisting of a base or reference rate plus a margin, and were often also associated with a swap to hedge the interest rate risk.

Work behind the scenes

While zero floor agreements protect the bank from the base or reference rate falling through zero and see the borrower simply charged the bank's full margin, swaps that are supposed to protect the borrower do not and leave the borrower exposed.

“In this inverted world, the borrower can end up paying twice,” Mr Elias said.

The practical implications of negative rates have become a hot topic after the cash rate was cut by the Reserve Bank to a record low 0.75 per cent last week.

The issue was further stoked when the RBA published a report on Tuesday which explored the impact of unconventional monetary policy, including negative rates.

Advertisement

RBA governor Philip Lowe told a parliamentary hearing in August he hoped to avoid negative interest rates, but stood ready to do unconventional things if required.

With most banks' systems unlikely to cope with the challenges of applying negative interest rates to millions of retail customers, banks are expected to target the highest value customers first if negative interest rates do come to pass.

Banks say there is a lot of work going on behind the scenes as they map out the impact of rates at zero or even lower.

If rates went far enough below zero the banks would technically have to pay borrowers, though MinterEllison's lawyers say this is unlikely.

“For most transactions, this would not lead to an obligation on the lender to pay the borrower – the interest obligations under most facility agreements are expressed solely as an obligation on the borrower to pay,” the company said in a note to clients.

Zero floor clauses have become standard in Australian loan documents based on the Asia Pacific Loan Market Association (APLMA) loan agreement template, after European banks introduced a LIBOR floor for loans following the global financial crisis.

UBS introduced a series of staggered negative interest rates charges in July for wealth customers.

Advertisement

European banks have more recently started introducing initiatives designed to offset the other side of negative interest rates by charging high-net-worth customers with large deposits.

In Switzerland – where the central bank has set interest rates at negative 0.75 per cent since 2015 – large Swiss banks have finally capitulated and started charging wealthy clients for holding deposits.

UBS introduced a series of staggered negative interest rates charges in July for wealth customers.

Customers with more than €500,000 ($814,000) in cash are charged 0.6 per cent, while customers with more than €2 million are charged 0.75 per cent.

Credit Suisse followed the lead of its rival and introduced a charge of 0.4 per cent on accounts holding €1 million in September, and is reportedly about to extend the charge to accounts holding Swiss francs.

A flyer for the bank’s cash deposit account does not spell out the charge but merely says “the current negative interest rate will be communicated to you on request”.

The issue of zero floor agreements may also have implications for institutional depositors. Much as the banks are protecting themselves, customers holding large deposits are expected to be keen to prevent their cash from being eaten away in such a topsy-turvy environment.
description: Banks and their biggest customers are checking the fine print of loan agreements for clauses that place a floor on interest rates.
